So idk if this is helpful to anyone but... don’t beatup on yourself for needing to grow out of a fixed mindset and being a beginner there, and know that the framework as often presented downplays or ignores systemic aspects of identity as watered-dein psych for Ed often does

And when I go hard back into fixed mindset for a time - usually when I’m depressed, triggered in my PTSD, in physical pain reminds me of patient core identity, or feels like stakes are high either for my life or in ways that are too close to what I ingrained in self growing up

This is why, I think, now so drawn to craft and workshop models, accountable communities, coaching models of learning, autonomy and self-efficacy as foci in SPED; has made me more joyful and doing better, more public work in PhD too

most powerful professional change for me was model of “gifted behavior”, creativity and problem solving (Renzulli, Sternberg) over trait-model “giftedness”; personally, as 2e, it was when I could week help, handle feedback, was a beginner Yes w/aptitude in langs not hotshot math

And rejected gifted label for so long b/c it meant to most saying it what the teachers who praised my grades meant - “better, special” - and I knew i was predisposed to have that go to my head - partly b/c as disabled got opposite from society, “broken, worse”

I think I had a fixed mindset thru most of 6-12 (when officially in G&T and not inclusion) but knew intuitively the kids praised less for their scored were doing much more interesting things, smarter, that I’d get into the fancy school but they’d do cooler stuff and more, was sad

Reading Dweck on mindset in book form. Still skimming most of it, not interested in the simple dogma, but in the feels and stuff to talk about re: 2e and disability: tension b/w intuiting that process more impt than perf, praise for perf, and needing an ID other than patient 1/

OK so, leaning towards Mendeley, though still have to figure out Dropox role there / dealing with duplicates / where files stored.

Horror or love stories for Mendeley for a diss and managing post-PhD scholarly work?

@profyarrow And, vice versa, thanks for being open about your LD as a professor. It was and continues to be so so powerful for me in rejecting shame in aca spaces and asking for help/accommodations for own stuff (tho still v hard on myself and often don’t ask!)

@profyarrow Yep. It’s a mess. Chronic patients,  those affected, we’re often more informed than indie experts... and man is that a hard place to be often. Also hits me in the gut as a languages type - “why can no-one give me & I can’t find words that fit, it/I must be totally alien/f’ed up”

often less impt than utility - both practical intervention and how the person with it can hold various dxes as part of their identity. (To me, theory angle, choice b/w 2 labels  both fitting somewhat really impt to get right if implications for intervention diff, if not, ehh)

BIG disclaimer, I’m a chronic patient, sensory-something sufferer, and self-advocate of a sort, had an IEP as kid; along with teach folks w/this in part if profile - NOT a clinician, researcher, licensed anything but teacher. But yeah - from pt side ”truth” of dx (mess w/DSM) 1/

also consider: lotsa issues at stake. Depending on age, functioning, rsrcs, location, on and on, I’ve seen often where an ASD diagnosis may help more anyway in terms of insurance, eligibility for services under IDEA and ADA, and state, nat’l progs, funding. Stigma naturally too.

Myself as someone trained in special ed and amateur psych research lit consumer, not sure it’s coherent enough or possible etiology conceivable enough to be a diagnostic category, rather than another part to consider in several Dxes. (like how ADHD-like stuff oft ”really” trauma)

Also, if you read about SPD and feel you have it - good language to talk to your doc - primary, neuro, psych, or OT, etc - beware for some it is like fibromyalgia, dismissed by individuals and by the field of psych, tho many more will agree there’s something there.
